text: And the whole community of the Israelites and the resident foreigner who lives among them will be forgiven, since all the people were involved in the unintentional offense.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘If any person sins unintentionally, then he must bring a yearling female goat for a purification offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the priest must make atonement for the person who sins unintentionally—when he sins unintentionally before the Lord—to make atonement for him, and he will be forgiven.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have one law for the person who sins unintentionally, both for the native-born among the Israelites and for the resident foreigner who lives among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But the person who acts defiantly, whether native-born or a resident foreigner, insults the Lord. That person must be cut off from among his people.
speaker: Narrator

text: Because he has despised the Lord’s message and has broken his commandment, that person must be completely cut off. His iniquity will be on him.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Israelites were in the wilderness they found a man gathering wood on the Sabbath day.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those who found him gathering wood brought him to Moses and Aaron and to the whole community.
speaker: Narrator

text: They put him in custody, because there was no clear instruction about what should be done to him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “The man must surely be put to death; the whole community must stone him with stones outside the camp.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the whole community took him outside the camp and stoned him to death, just as the Lord commanded Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites and tell them to make tassels for themselves on the corners of their garments throughout their generations, and put a blue thread on the tassel of the corners.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must have this tassel so that you may look at it and remember all the commandments of the Lord and obey them and so that you do not follow after your own heart and your own eyes that lead you to unfaithfulness.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus you will remember and obey all my commandments and be holy to your God.
speaker: Narrator

text: I am the Lord your God, who brought you out of the land of Egypt to be your God. I am the Lord your God.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Korah son of Izhar, the son of Kohath, the son of Levi, and Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, and On son of Peleth, who were Reubenites, took men
speaker: Narrator

text: and rebelled against Moses, along with some of the Israelites, 250 leaders of the community, chosen from the assembly, famous men.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they assembled against Moses and Aaron, saying to them, “You take too much upon yourselves, seeing that the whole community is holy, every one of them, and the Lord is among them. Why then do you exalt yourselves above the community of the Lord?”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Moses heard it he fell down with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then he said to Korah and to all his company, “In the morning the Lord will make known who are his, and who is holy. He will cause that person to approach him; the person he has chosen he will cause to approach him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Do this, Korah, you and all your company: Take censers,
speaker: Narrator

text: put fire in them, and set incense on them before the Lord tomorrow, and the man whom the Lord chooses will be holy. You take too much upon yourselves, you sons of Levi!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to Korah, “Listen now, you sons of Levi!
speaker: Narrator

text: Does it seem too small a thing to you that the God of Israel has separated you from the community of Israel to bring you near to himself, to perform the service of the tabernacle of the Lord, and to stand before the community to minister to them?
speaker: Narrator

text: He has brought you near and all your brothers, the sons of Levi, with you. Do you now seek the priesthood also?
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore you and all your company have assembled together against the Lord! And Aaron—what is he that you murmur against him?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses summoned Dathan and Abiram, the sons of Eliab, but they said, “We will not come up.
speaker: Narrator

text: Is it a small thing that you have brought us up out of the land that flows with milk and honey, to kill us in the wilderness? Now do you want to make yourself a prince over us?
speaker: Narrator

text: Moreover, you have not brought us into a land that flows with milk and honey, nor given us an inheritance of fields and vineyards. Do you think you can blind these men? We will not come up.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses was very angry, and he said to the Lord, “Have no respect for their offering! I have not taken so much as one donkey from them, nor have I harmed any one of them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Korah, “You and all your company present yourselves before the Lord—you and they, and Aaron—tomorrow.
speaker: Narrator

text: And each of you take his censer, put incense in it, and then each of you present his censer before the Lord: 250 censers, along with you, and Aaron—each of you with his censer.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So everyone took his censer, put fire in it, and set incense on it, and stood at the entrance of the tent of meeting, with Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Korah assembled the whole community against them at the entrance of the tent of meeting, then the glory of the Lord appeared to the whole community.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Separate yourselves from among this community, that I may consume them in an instant.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they threw themselves down with their faces to the ground and said, “O God, the God of the spirits of all people, will you be angry with the whole community when only one man sins?”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell the community: ‘Get away from around the homes of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses got up and went to Dathan and Abiram; and the elders of Israel went after him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he said to the community, “Move away from the tents of these wicked men, and do not touch anything they have, lest you be destroyed because of all their sins.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they got away from the homes of Korah, Dathan, and Abiram on every side, and Dathan and Abiram came out and stationed themselves in the entrances of their tents with their wives, their children, and their toddlers.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said, “This is how you will know that the Lord has sent me to do all these works, for I have not done them of my own will.
speaker: Narrator

text: If these men die a natural death, or if they share the fate of all men, then the Lord has not sent me.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if the Lord does something entirely new, and the earth opens its mouth and swallows them up along with all that they have, and they go down alive to the grave, then you will know that these men have despised the Lord!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When he had finished speaking all these words, the ground that was under them split open,
speaker: Narrator

text: and the earth opened its mouth and swallowed them, along with their households, and all Korah’s men, and all their goods.
speaker: Narrator

text: They and all that they had went down alive into the pit, and the earth closed over them. So they perished from among the community.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the Israelites who were around them fled at their cry, for they said, “What if the earth swallows us too?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a fire went out from the Lord and devoured the 250 men who offered incense.
speaker: Narrator

text: (17:1) The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Tell Eleazar son of Aaron the priest to pick up the censers out of the flame, for they are holy, and then scatter the coals of fire at a distance.
speaker: Narrator

text: As for the censers of these men who sinned at the cost of their lives, they must be made into hammered sheets for covering the altar, because they presented them before the Lord and sanctified them. They will become a sign to the Israelites.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Eleazar the priest took the bronze censers presented by those who had been burned up, and they were hammered out as a covering for the altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: It was a memorial for the Israelites, that no outsider who is not a descendant of Aaron should approach to burn incense before the Lord, that he might not become like Korah and his company—just as the Lord had spoken by the authority of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: But on the next day the whole community of Israelites murmured against Moses and Aaron, saying, “You have killed the Lord’s people!”
speaker: Narrator

text: When the community assembled against Moses and Aaron, they turned toward the tent of meeting—and the cloud covered it, and the glory of the Lord appeared.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron stood before the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Get away from this community, so that I can consume them in an instant!” But they threw themselves down with their faces to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses said to Aaron, “Take the censer, put burning coals from the altar in it, place incense on it, and go quickly into the assembly and make atonement for them, for wrath has gone out from the Lord—the plague has begun!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Aaron did as Moses commanded and ran into the middle of the assembly, where the plague was just beginning among the people. So he placed incense on the coals and made atonement for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: He stood between the dead and the living, and the plague was stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now 14,700 people died in the plague, in addition to those who died in the event with Korah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Aaron returned to Moses at the entrance of the tent of meeting, and the plague was stopped.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Speak to the Israelites, and receive from them a staff from each tribe, one from every tribal leader, twelve staffs; you must write each man’s name on his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must write Aaron’s name on the staff of Levi; for one staff is for the head of every tribe.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must place them in the tent of meeting before the ark of the covenant where I meet with you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the staff of the man whom I choose will blossom; so I will rid myself of the complaints of the Israelites, which they murmur against you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke to the Israelites, and each of their leaders gave him a staff, one for each leader, according to their tribes—twelve staffs; the staff of Aaron was among their staffs.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses placed the staffs before the Lord in the tent of the testimony.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the next day Moses went into the tent of the testimony—and the staff of Aaron for the house of Levi had sprouted, and brought forth buds, and produced blossoms, and yielded almonds!
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses brought out all the staffs from before the Lord to all the Israelites. They looked at them, and each man took his staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Bring Aaron’s staff back before the testimony to be preserved for a sign to the rebels, so that you may bring their murmurings to an end before me, that they will not die.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses did as the Lord commanded him—this is what he did.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites said to Moses, “We are bound to die! We perish, we all perish!
speaker: Narrator

text: (17:28) Anyone who even comes close to the tabernacle of the Lord will die! Are we all to die?”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Aaron, “You and your sons and your tribe with you must bear the iniquity of the sanctuary, and you and your sons with you must bear the iniquity of your priesthood.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Bring with you your brothers, the tribe of Levi, the tribe of your father, so that they may join with you and minister to you while you and your sons with you are before the tent of the testimony.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must be responsible to care for you and to care for the entire tabernacle. However, they must not come near the furnishings of the sanctuary and the altar, or both they and you will die.
speaker: Narrator

text: They must join with you, and they will be responsible for the care of the tent of meeting, for all the service of the tent, but no unauthorized person may approach you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You will be responsible for the care of the sanctuary and the care of the altar, so that there will be no more wrath on the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: I myself have chosen your brothers the Levites from among the Israelites. They are given to you as a gift from the Lord, to perform the duties of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you and your sons with you are responsible for your priestly duties, for everything at the altar and within the curtain. And you must serve. I give you the priesthood as a gift for service, but the unauthorized person who approaches must be put to death.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Aaron, “See, I have given you the responsibility for my raised offerings; I have given all the holy things of the Israelites to you as your priestly portion and to your sons as a perpetual ordinance.
speaker: Narrator

text: Of all the most holy offerings reserved from the fire this will be yours: Every offering of theirs, whether from every grain offering or from every purification offering or from every reparation offering which they bring to me, will be most holy for you and for your sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to eat it as a most holy offering; every male may eat it. It will be holy to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And this is yours: the raised offering of their gift, along with all the wave offerings of the Israelites. I have given them to you and to your sons and daughters with you as a perpetual ordinance. Everyone who is ceremonially clean in your household may eat of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “All the best of the olive oil and all the best of the wine and of the wheat, the firstfruits of these things that they give to the Lord, I have given to you.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whatever first ripe fruit in their land they bring to the Lord will be yours; everyone who is ceremonially clean in your household may eat of it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Everything devoted in Israel will be yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: The firstborn of every womb which they present to the Lord, whether human or animal, will be yours. Nevertheless, the firstborn sons you must redeem, and the firstborn males of unclean animals you must redeem.
speaker: Narrator

text: And those that must be redeemed you are to redeem when they are a month old, according to your estimation, for five shekels of silver according to the sanctuary shekel (which is twenty gerahs).
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must not redeem the firstborn of a cow or a sheep or a goat; they are holy. You must splash their blood on the altar and burn their fat for an offering made by fire for a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: And their meat will be yours, just as the breast and the right hip of the raised offering is yours.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the raised offerings of the holy things that the Israelites offer to the Lord, I have given to you, and to your sons and daughters with you, as a perpetual ordinance. It is a covenant of salt forever before the Lord for you and for your descendants with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Aaron, “You will have no inheritance in their land, nor will you have any portion of property among them—I am your portion and your inheritance among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: See, I have given the Levites all the tithes in Israel for an inheritance, for their service that they perform—the service of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: No longer may the Israelites approach the tent of meeting, or else they will bear their sin and die.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Levites must perform the service of the tent of meeting, and they must bear their iniquity. It will be a perpetual ordinance throughout your generations that among the Israelites the Levites have no inheritance.
speaker: Narrator

text: But I have given to the Levites for an inheritance the tithes of the Israelites that are offered to the Lord as a raised offering. That is why I said to them that among the Israelites they are to have no inheritance.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “You are to speak to the Levites, and you must tell them, ‘When you receive from the Israelites the tithe that I have given you from them as your inheritance, then you are to offer up from it as a raised offering to the Lord a tenth of the tithe.
speaker: Narrator

text: And your raised offering will be credited to you as though it were grain from the threshing floor or as new wine from the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: Thus you are to offer up a raised offering to the Lord of all your tithes that you receive from the Israelites; and you must give the Lord’s raised offering from it to Aaron the priest.
speaker: Narrator

text: From all your gifts you must offer up every raised offering due the Lord, from all the best of it, and the holiest part of it.’
speaker: Narrator

text: “Therefore you will say to them, ‘When you offer up the best of it, then it will be credited to the Levites as the product of the threshing floor and as the product of the winepress.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you may eat it in any place, you and your household, because it is your wages for your service in the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you will bear no sin concerning it when you offer up the best of it. And you must not profane the holy things of the Israelites, or else you will die.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron:
speaker: Narrator

text: “This is the ordinance of the law that the Lord has commanded: ‘Instruct the Israelites to bring you a red heifer without blemish, which has no defect and has never carried a yoke.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must give it to Eleazar the priest so that he can take it outside the camp, and it must be slaughtered before him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eleazar the priest is to take some of its blood with his finger, and sprinkle some of the blood seven times in the direction of the front of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the heifer must be burned in his sight—its skin, its flesh, its blood, and its offal is to be burned.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the priest must take cedar wood, hyssop, and scarlet wool and throw them into the midst of the fire where the heifer is burning.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the priest must wash his clothes and bathe himself in water, and afterward he may come into the camp, but the priest will be ceremonially unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who burns it must wash his clothes in water and bathe himself in water. He will be ceremonially unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Then a man who is ceremonially clean must gather up the ashes of the red heifer and put them in a ceremonially clean place outside the camp. They must be kept for the community of the Israelites for use in the water of purification—it is a purification for sin.
speaker: Narrator

text: The one who gathers the ashes of the heifer must wash his clothes and be ceremonially unclean until evening. This will be a permanent ordinance both for the Israelites and the resident foreigner who lives among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Whoever touches the corpse of any person will be ceremonially unclean seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: He must purify himself with water on the third day and on the seventh day, and so will be clean. But if he does not purify himself on the third day and the seventh day, then he will not be clean.
speaker: Narrator

text: Anyone who touches the corpse of any dead person and does not purify himself defiles the tabernacle of the Lord. And that person must be cut off from Israel, because the water of purification was not sprinkled on him. He will be unclean; his uncleanness remains on him.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘This is the law: When a man dies in a tent, anyone who comes into the tent and all who are in the tent will be ceremonially unclean seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: And every open container that has no covering fastened on it is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whoever touches the body of someone killed with a sword in the open fields, or the body of someone who died of natural causes, or a human bone, or a grave, will be unclean seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘For a ceremonially unclean person you must take some of the ashes of the heifer burnt for purification from sin and pour fresh running water over them in a vessel.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then a ceremonially clean person must take hyssop, dip it in the water, and sprinkle it on the tent, on all its furnishings, and on the people who were there, or on the one who touched a bone, or one who was killed, or one who died, or a grave.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the clean person must sprinkle the unclean on the third day and on the seventh day; and on the seventh day he must purify him, and then he must wash his clothes, and bathe in water, and he will be clean in the evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the man who is unclean and does not purify himself, that person must be cut off from among the community, because he has polluted the sanctuary of the Lord; the water of purification was not sprinkled on him, so he is unclean.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘So this will be a perpetual ordinance for them: The one who sprinkles the water of purification must wash his clothes, and the one who touches the water of purification will be unclean until evening.
speaker: Narrator

text: And whatever the unclean person touches will be unclean, and the person who touches it will be unclean until evening.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the entire community of Israel entered the wilderness of Zin in the first month, and the people stayed in Kadesh. Miriam died and was buried there.
speaker: Narrator

text: And there was no water for the community, and so they gathered themselves together against Moses and Aaron.
speaker: Narrator

text: The people contended with Moses, saying, “If only we had died when our brothers died before the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you brought up the Lord’s community into this wilderness? So that we and our cattle should die here?
speaker: Narrator

text: Why have you brought us up from Egypt only to bring us to this dreadful place? It is no place for grain, or figs, or vines, or pomegranates; nor is there any water to drink!”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Aaron went from the presence of the assembly to the entrance to the tent of meeting. They then threw themselves down with their faces to the ground, and the glory of the Lord appeared to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take the staff and assemble the community, you and Aaron your brother, and then speak to the rock before their eyes. It will pour forth its water, and you will bring water out of the rock for them, and so you will give the community and their beasts water to drink.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses took the staff from before the Lord, just as he commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses and Aaron gathered the community together in front of the rock, and he said to them, “Listen, you rebels, must we bring water out of this rock for you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses raised his hand, and struck the rock twice with his staff. And water came out abundantly. So the community drank, and their beasts drank too.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron, “Because you did not trust me enough to show me as holy before the Israelites, therefore you will not bring this community into the land I have given them.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the waters of Meribah, because the Israelites contended with the Lord, and his holiness was maintained among them.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent messengers from Kadesh to the king of Edom: “Thus says your brother Israel: ‘You know all the hardships we have experienced,
speaker: Narrator

text: how our ancestors went down into Egypt, and we lived in Egypt a long time, and the Egyptians treated us and our ancestors badly.
speaker: Narrator

text: So when we cried to the Lord, he heard our voice and sent a messenger, and has brought us up out of Egypt. Now we are here in Kadesh, a town on the edge of your country.
speaker: Narrator

text: Please let us pass through your country. We will not pass through the fields or through the vineyards, nor will we drink water from any well. We will go by the King’s Highway; we will not turn to the right or the left until we have passed through your region.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Edom said to him, “You will not pass through me, or I will come out against you with the sword.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Israelites said to him, “We will go along the highway, and if we or our cattle drink any of your water, we will pay for it. We will only pass through on our feet, without doing anything else.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But he said, “You may not pass through.” Then Edom came out against them with a large and powerful force.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Edom refused to give Israel passage through his border; therefore Israel turned away from him.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the entire company of Israelites traveled from Kadesh and came to Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord spoke to Moses and Aaron at Mount Hor, by the border of the land of Edom. He said:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Aaron will be gathered to his ancestors, for he will not enter into the land I have given to the Israelites because both of you rebelled against my word at the waters of Meribah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Take Aaron and Eleazar his son, and bring them up on Mount Hor.
speaker: Narrator

text: Remove Aaron’s priestly garments and put them on Eleazar his son, and Aaron will be gathered to his ancestors and will die there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses did as the Lord commanded; and they went up Mount Hor in the sight of the whole community.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Moses removed Aaron’s garments and put them on his son Eleazar. So Aaron died there on the top of the mountain. And Moses and Eleazar came down from the mountain.
speaker: Narrator

text: When all the community saw that Aaron was dead, the whole house of Israel mourned for Aaron thirty days.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the Canaanite king of Arad who lived in the Negev heard that Israel was approaching along the road to Atharim, he fought against Israel and took some of them prisoner.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel made a vow to the Lord and said, “If you will indeed deliver this people into our hand, then we will utterly destroy their cities.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord listened to the voice of Israel and delivered up the Canaanites, and they utterly destroyed them and their cities. So the name of the place was called Hormah.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they traveled from Mount Hor by the road to the Red Sea, to go around the land of Edom, but the people became impatient along the way.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the people spoke against God and against Moses, “Why have you brought us up from Egypt to die in the wilderness, for there is no bread or water, and we detest this worthless food.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Lord sent venomous snakes among the people, and they bit the people; many people of Israel died.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the people came to Moses and said, “We have sinned, for we have spoken against the Lord and against you. Pray to the Lord that he would take away the snakes from us.” So Moses prayed for the people.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Make a poisonous snake and set it on a pole. When anyone who is bitten looks at it, he will live.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses made a bronze snake and put it on a pole, so that if a snake had bitten someone, when he looked at the bronze snake he lived.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites traveled on and camped in Oboth.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they traveled on from Oboth and camped at Iye Abarim, in the wilderness that is before Moab on the eastern side.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they moved on and camped in the valley of Zered.
speaker: Narrator

text: From there they moved on and camped on the other side of the Arnon, in the wilderness that extends from the regions of the Amorites, for Arnon is the border of Moab, between Moab and the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
This is why it is said in the Book of the Wars of the Lord,
“Waheb in Suphah and the wadis,
the Arnon
speaker: Narrator

text:
and the slope of the valleys
that extends to the dwelling of Ar,
and falls off at the border of Moab.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And from there they traveled to Beer; that is the well where the Lord spoke to Moses, “Gather the people and I will give them water.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Israel sang this song:
“Spring up, O well, sing to it!
speaker: Narrator

text:
The well which the princes dug,
which the leaders of the people opened
with their scepters and their staffs.” 
And from the wilderness they traveled to Mattanah;
speaker: Narrator

text: and from Mattanah to Nahaliel; and from Nahaliel to Bamoth;
speaker: Narrator

text: and from Bamoth to the valley that is in the country of Moab, near the top of Pisgah, which overlooks the wastelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Israel sent messengers to King Sihon of the Amorites, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let us pass through your land; we will not turn aside into the fields or into the vineyards, nor will we drink water from any well, but we will go along the King’s Highway until we pass your borders.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Sihon did not permit Israel to pass through his border; he gathered all his forces together and went out against Israel into the wilderness. When he came to Jahaz, he fought against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the Israelites defeated him in battle and took possession of his land from the Arnon to the Jabbok, as far as the Ammonites, for the border of the Ammonites was strongly defended.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Israel took all these cities; and Israel settled in all the cities of the Amorites, in Heshbon, and in all its villages.
speaker: Narrator

text: For Heshbon was the city of King Sihon of the Amorites. Now he had fought against the former king of Moab and had taken all his land from his control, as far as the Arnon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
That is why those who speak in proverbs say,
“Come to Heshbon, let it be built.
Let the city of Sihon be established!
speaker: Narrator

text:
For fire went out from Heshbon,
a flame from the city of Sihon.
It has consumed Ar of Moab
and the lords of the high places of Arnon.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Woe to you, Moab.
You are ruined, O people of Chemosh!
He has made his sons fugitives,
and his daughters the prisoners of King Sihon of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text:
We have overpowered them;
Heshbon has perished as far as Dibon.
We have shattered them as far as Nophah,
which reaches to Medeba.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Israelites lived in the land of the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses sent spies to reconnoiter Jazer, and they captured its villages and dispossessed the Amorites who were there.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then they turned and went up by the road to Bashan. And King Og of Bashan and all his forces marched out against them to do battle at Edrei.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Lord said to Moses, “Do not fear him, for I have delivered him and all his people and his land into your hand. You will do to him what you did to King Sihon of the Amorites, who lived in Heshbon.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So they defeated Og, his sons, and all his people, until there were no survivors, and they possessed his land.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites traveled on and camped in the rift valley plains of Moab on the side of the Jordan River across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak son of Zippor saw all that the Israelites had done to the Amorites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Moabites were greatly afraid of the people, because they were so numerous. The Moabites were sick with fear because of the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: So the Moabites said to the elders of Midian, “Now this mass of people will lick up everything around us, as the bull devours the grass of the field.” Now Balak son of Zippor was king of the Moabites at this time.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he sent messengers to Balaam son of Beor at Pethor, which is by the Euphrates River in the land of Amaw, to summon him, saying, “Look, a nation has come out of Egypt. They cover the face of the earth, and they are settling next to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, please come and curse this nation for me, for they are too powerful for me. Perhaps I will prevail so that we may conquer them and drive them out of the land. For I know that whoever you bless is blessed, and whoever you curse is cursed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the elders of Moab and the elders of Midian departed with the fee for divination in their hands. They came to Balaam and reported to him the words of Balak.
speaker: Narrator

text: He replied to them, “Stay here tonight, and I will bring back to you whatever word the Lord may speak to me.” So the princes of Moab stayed with Balaam.
speaker: Narrator

text: And God came to Balaam and said, “Who are these men with you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to God, “Balak son of Zippor, king of Moab, has sent a message to me, saying,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘Look, a nation has come out of Egypt, and it covers the face of the earth. Come now and put a curse on them for me; perhaps I will be able to defeat them and drive them out.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: But God said to Balaam, “You must not go with them; you must not curse the people, for they are blessed.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balaam got up in the morning, and said to the princes of Balak, “Go to your land, for the Lord has refused to permit me to go with you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So the princes of Moab departed and went back to Balak and said, “Balaam refused to come with us.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak again sent princes, more numerous and more distinguished than the first.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they came to Balaam and said to him, “Thus says Balak son of Zippor: ‘Please do not let anything hinder you from coming to me.
speaker: Narrator

text: For I will honor you greatly, and whatever you tell me I will do. So come, put a curse on this nation for me.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam replied to the servants of Balak, “Even if Balak would give me his palace full of silver and gold, I could not transgress the commandment of the Lord my God to do less or more.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore, please stay the night here also, that I may know what more the Lord might say to me.”
speaker: Narrator

text: God came to Balaam that night, and said to him, “If the men have come to call you, get up and go with them, but the word that I will say to you, that you must do.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balaam got up in the morning, saddled his donkey, and went with the princes of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God’s anger was kindled because he went, and the angel of the Lord stood in the road to oppose him. Now he was riding on his donkey and his two servants were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the donkey saw the angel of the Lord standing in the road with his sword drawn in his hand, so the donkey turned aside from the road and went into the field. But Balaam beat the donkey, to make her turn back to the road.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord stood in a path among the vineyards, where there was a wall on either side.
speaker: Narrator

text: And when the donkey saw the angel of the Lord, she pressed herself into the wall, and crushed Balaam’s foot against the wall. So he beat her again.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the angel of the Lord went farther, and stood in a narrow place, where there was no way to turn either to the right or to the left.
speaker: Narrator

text: When the donkey saw the angel of the Lord, she crouched down under Balaam. Then Balaam was angry, and he beat his donkey with a staff.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord opened the mouth of the donkey, and she said to Balaam, “What have I done to you that you have beaten me these three times?”
speaker: Narrator

text: And Balaam said to the donkey, “You have made me look stupid; I wish there were a sword in my hand, for I would kill you right now.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey said to Balaam, “Am I not your donkey that you have ridden ever since I was yours until this day? Have I ever attempted to treat you this way?” And he said, “No.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord opened Balaam’s eyes, and he saw the angel of the Lord standing in the way with his sword drawn in his hand; so he bowed his head and threw himself down with his face to the ground.
speaker: Narrator

text: The angel of the Lord said to him, “Why have you beaten your donkey these three times? Look, I came out to oppose you because what you are doing is perverse before me.
speaker: Narrator

text: The donkey saw me and turned from me these three times. If she had not turned from me, I would have killed you but saved her alive.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to the angel of the Lord, “I have sinned, for I did not know that you stood against me in the road. So now, if it is evil in your sight, I will go back home.”
speaker: Narrator

text: But the angel of the Lord said to Balaam, “Go with the men, but you may only speak the word that I will speak to you.” So Balaam went with the princes of Balak.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balak heard that Balaam was coming, he went out to meet him at a city of Moab that was on the border of the Arnon at the boundary of his territory.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Did I not send again and again to you to summon you? Why did you not come to me? Am I not able to honor you?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Look, I have come to you. Now, am I able to speak just anything? I must speak only the word that God puts in my mouth.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balaam went with Balak, and they came to Kiriath Huzoth.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Balak sacrificed bulls and sheep, and sent some to Balaam, and to the princes who were with him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then on the next morning Balak took Balaam, and brought him up to Bamoth Baal. From there he saw the extent of the nation.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Build me seven altars here, and prepare for me here seven bulls and seven rams.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balak did just as Balaam had said. Balak and Balaam then offered on each altar a bull and a ram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Station yourself by your burnt offering, and I will go off; perhaps the Lord will come to meet me, and whatever he reveals to me I will tell you.” Then he went to a deserted height.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then God met Balaam, who said to him, “I have prepared seven altars, and I have offered on each altar a bull and a ram.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord put a message in Balaam’s mouth and said, “Return to Balak, and speak what I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So he returned to him, and he was still standing by his burnt offering, he and all the princes of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Balaam uttered his oracle, saying,
“Balak, the king of Moab, brought me from Aram,
out of the mountains of the east, saying,
‘Come, pronounce a curse on Jacob for me;
come, denounce Israel.’
speaker: Narrator

text:
How can I curse one whom God has not cursed,
or how can I denounce one whom the Lord has not denounced?
speaker: Narrator

text:
For from the top of the rocks I see them;
from the hills I watch them.
Indeed, a nation that lives alone,
and it will not be reckoned among the nations.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Who can count the dust of Jacob,
or number the fourth part of Israel?
Let me die the death of the upright,
and let the end of my life be like theirs.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak said to Balaam, “What have you done to me? I brought you to curse my enemies, but on the contrary you have only blessed them!”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam replied, “Must I not be careful to speak what the Lord has put in my mouth?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to him, “Please come with me to another place from which you can observe them. You will see only a part of them, but you will not see all of them. Curse them for me from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balak brought Balaam to the field of Zophim, to the top of Pisgah, where he built seven altars and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: And Balaam said to Balak, “Station yourself here by your burnt offering, while I meet the Lord there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord met Balaam and put a message in his mouth and said, “Return to Balak, and speak what I tell you.”
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam came to him, he was still standing by his burnt offering, along with the princes of Moab. And Balak said to him, “What has the Lord spoken?”
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
God is not a man, that he should lie,
nor a human being, that he should change his mind.
Has he said, and will he not do it?
Or has he spoken, and will he not make it happen?
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, I have received a command to bless;
he has blessed, and I cannot reverse it.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He has not looked on iniquity in Jacob,
nor has he seen trouble in Israel.
The Lord their God is with them;
his acclamation as king is among them.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God brought them out of Egypt.
They have, as it were, the strength of a wild bull.
speaker: Narrator

text:
For there is no spell against Jacob,
nor is there any divination against Israel.
At this time it must be said of Jacob
and of Israel, ‘Look at what God has done!’
speaker: Narrator

text:
Indeed, the people will rise up like a lioness,
and like a lion raises himself up;
they will not lie down until they eat their prey,
and drink the blood of the slain.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Neither curse them at all nor bless them at all!”
speaker: Narrator

text: But Balaam replied to Balak, “Did I not tell you, ‘All that the Lord speaks, I must do’?”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balak said to Balaam, “Come, please; I will take you to another place. Perhaps it will please God to let you curse them for me from there.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balak took Balaam to the top of Peor, that looks toward the wastelands.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balaam said to Balak, “Build seven altars here for me, and prepare seven bulls and seven rams.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Balak did as Balaam had said, and offered a bull and a ram on each altar.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam saw that it pleased the Lord to bless Israel, he did not go as at the other times to seek for omens, but he set his face toward the wilderness.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Balaam lifted up his eyes, he saw Israel camped tribe by tribe; and the Spirit of God came upon him.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he uttered this oracle:
“The oracle of Balaam son of Beor,
the oracle of the man whose eyes are open,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the oracle of the one who hears the words of God,
who sees a vision from the Almighty,
although falling flat on the ground with eyes open:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘How beautiful are your tents, O Jacob,
and your dwelling places, O Israel!
speaker: Narrator

text:
They are like valleys stretched forth,
like gardens by the river’s side,
like aloes that the Lord has planted,
and like cedar trees beside the waters.
speaker: Narrator

text:
He will pour the water out of his buckets,
and their descendants will be like abundant water;
their king will be greater than Agag,
and their kingdom will be exalted.
speaker: Narrator

text:
God brought them out of Egypt.
They have, as it were, the strength of a young bull;
they will devour hostile people,
and will break their bones,
and will pierce them through with arrows.
speaker: Narrator

text:
They crouch and lie down like a lion,
and as a lioness, who can stir him?
Blessed is the one who blesses you,
and cursed is the one who curses you!’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Balak became very angry at Balaam, and he struck his hands together. Balak said to Balaam, “I called you to curse my enemies, and look, you have done nothing but bless them these three times!
speaker: Narrator

text: So now, go back where you came from! I said that I would greatly honor you, but now the Lord has stood in the way of your honor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam said to Balak, “Did I not also tell your messengers whom you sent to me,
speaker: Narrator

text: ‘If Balak would give me his palace full of silver and gold, I cannot go beyond the commandment of the Lord to do either good or evil of my own will, but whatever the Lord tells me I must speak’?
speaker: Narrator

text: And now, I am about to go back to my own people. Come now, and I will advise you as to what this people will do to your people in future days.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he uttered this oracle:
“The oracle of Balaam son of Beor,
the oracle of the man whose eyes are open,
speaker: Narrator

text:
the oracle of the one who hears the words of God,
and who knows the knowledge of the Most High,
who sees a vision from the Almighty,
although falling flat on the ground with eyes open:
speaker: Narrator

text:
‘I see him, but not now;
I behold him, but not close at hand.
A star will march forth out of Jacob,
and a scepter will rise out of Israel.
He will crush the skulls of Moab,
and the heads of all the sons of Sheth.
speaker: Narrator
Narrator

text:
A ruler will be established from Jacob;
he will destroy the remains of the city.’”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then Balaam looked on Amalek and delivered this oracle:
“Amalek was the first of the nations,
but his end will be that he will perish.”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he looked on the Kenites and uttered this oracle:
“Your dwelling place seems strong,
and your nest is set on a rocky cliff.
speaker: Narrator

text:
Nevertheless the Kenite will be consumed.
How long will Asshur take you away captive?”
speaker: Narrator

text:
Then he uttered this oracle:
“O, who will survive when God does this!
speaker: Narrator

text:
Ships will come from the coast of Kittim,
and will afflict Asshur, and will afflict Eber,
and he will also perish forever.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Balaam got up and departed and returned to his home, and Balak also went his way.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel lived in Shittim, the people began to commit sexual immorality with the daughters of Moab.
speaker: Narrator

text: These women invited the people to the sacrifices of their gods; then the people ate and bowed down to their gods.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Israel joined themselves to Baal Peor, the anger of the Lord flared up against Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses, “Arrest all the leaders of the people, and hang them up before the Lord in broad daylight, so that the fierce anger of the Lord may be turned away from Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses said to the judges of Israel, “Each of you must execute those of his men who were joined to Baal Peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Just then one of the Israelites came and brought to his brothers a Midianite woman in the plain view of Moses and of the whole community of the Israelites, while they were weeping at the entrance of the tent of meeting.
speaker: Narrator

text: When Phinehas son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, saw it, he got up from among the assembly, took a javelin in his hand,
speaker: Narrator

text: and went after the Israelite man into the tent and thrust through the Israelite man and into the woman’s abdomen. So the plague was stopped from the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those that died in the plague were 24,000.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Phinehas son of Eleazar, the son of Aaron the priest, has turned my anger away from the Israelites, when he manifested such zeal for my sake among them, so that I did not consume the Israelites in my zeal.
speaker: Narrator

text: Therefore, announce: ‘I am going to give to him my covenant of peace.
speaker: Narrator

text: So it will be to him and his descendants after him a covenant of a permanent priesthood, because he has been zealous for his God, and has made atonement for the Israelites.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the name of the Israelite who was stabbed—the one who was stabbed with the Midianite woman—was Zimri son of Salu, a leader of a clan of the Simeonites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The name of the Midianite woman who was killed was Cozbi daughter of Zur. He was a leader over the people of a clan of Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Bring trouble to the Midianites, and destroy them,
speaker: Narrator

text: because they bring trouble to you by their treachery with which they have deceived you in the matter of Peor, and in the matter of Cozbi, the daughter of a prince of Midian, their sister, who was killed on the day of the plague that happened as a result of Peor.”
speaker: Narrator

text: After the plague the Lord said to Moses and to Eleazar son of Aaron the priest,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Take a census of the whole community of Israelites, from twenty years old and upward, by their clans, everyone who can serve in the army of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses and Eleazar the priest spoke with them in the rift valley plains of Moab, along the Jordan River across from Jericho. They said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Number the people from twenty years old and upward, just as the Lord commanded Moses and the Israelites who went out from the land of Egypt.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Reuben was the firstborn of Israel. The Reubenites: from Hanoch, the family of the Hanochites; from Pallu, the family of the Palluites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Hezron, the family of the Hezronites; from Carmi, the family of the Carmites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of the Reubenites; and those numbered of them were 43,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: Pallu’s descendant was Eliab.
speaker: Narrator

text: Eliab’s descendants were Nemuel, Dathan, and Abiram. It was Dathan and Abiram who as leaders of the community rebelled against Moses and Aaron with the followers of Korah when they rebelled against the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The earth opened its mouth and swallowed them and Korah at the time that company died, when the fire consumed 250 men. So they became a warning.
speaker: Narrator

text: But the descendants of Korah did not die.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Simeonites by their families: from Nemuel, the family of the Nemuelites; from Jamin, the family of the Jaminites; from Jakin, the family of the Jakinites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Zerah, the family of the Zerahites; and from Shaul, the family of the Shaulites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of the Simeonites, 22,200.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Gadites by their families: from Zephon, the family of the Zephonites; from Haggi, the family of the Haggites; from Shuni, the family of the Shunites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Ozni, the family of the Oznites; from Eri, the family of the Erites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Arod, the family of the Arodites; and from Areli, the family of the Arelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of the Gadites according to those numbered of them, 40,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Judah were Er and Onan, but Er and Onan died in the land of Canaan.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Judahites by their families were: from Shelah, the family of the Shelahites; from Perez, the family of the Perezites; and from Zerah, the family of the Zerahites.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the Perezites were: from Hezron, the family of the Hezronites; from Hamul, the family of the Hamulites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Judah according to those numbered of them, 76,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Issacharites by their families: from Tola, the family of the Tolaites; from Puah, the family of the Puites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Jashub, the family of the Jashubites; and from Shimron, the family of the Shimronites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Issachar, according to those numbered of them, 64,300.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Zebulunites by their families: from Sered, the family of the Sardites; from Elon, the family of the Elonites; from Jahleel, the family of the Jahleelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of the Zebulunites, according to those numbered of them, 60,500.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Joseph by their families: Manasseh and Ephraim.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Manassehites: from Machir, the family of the Machirites (now Machir became the father of Gilead); from Gilead, the family of the Gileadites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the Gileadites: from Iezer, the family of the Iezerites; from Helek, the family of the Helekites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Asriel, the family of the Asrielites; from Shechem, the family of the Shechemites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Shemida, the family of the Shemidaites; from Hepher, the family of the Hepherites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now Zelophehad son of Hepher had no sons, but only daughters; and the names of the daughters of Zelophehad were Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Manasseh; those numbered of them were 52,700.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the Ephraimites by their families: from Shuthelah, the family of the Shuthelahites; from Beker, the family of the Bekerites; from Tahan, the family of the Tahanites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now these were the Shuthelahites: from Eran, the family of the Eranites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of the Ephraimites, according to those numbered of them, 32,500. These were the descendants of Joseph by their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Benjaminites by their families: from Bela, the family of the Belaites; from Ashbel, the family of the Ashbelites; from Ahiram, the family of the Ahiramites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Shupham, the family of the Shuphamites; from Hupham, the family of the Huphamites.
speaker: Narrator

text: The descendants of Bela were Ard and Naaman. From Ard, the family of the Ardites; from Naaman, the family of the Naamanites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the Benjaminites, according to their families, and according to those numbered of them, 45,600.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the Danites by their families: from Shuham, the family of the Shuhamites. These were the families of Dan, according to their families.
speaker: Narrator

text: All the families of the Shuhamites according to those numbered of them were 64,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Asherites by their families: from Imnah, the family of the Imnahites; from Ishvi, the family of the Ishvites; from Beriah, the family of the Beriahites.
speaker: Narrator

text: From the Beriahites: from Heber, the family of the Heberites; from Malkiel, the family of the Malkielites.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the name of the daughter of Asher was Serah.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the Asherites, according to those numbered of them, 53,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Naphtalites by their families: from Jahzeel, the family of the Jahzeelites; from Guni, the family of the Gunites;
speaker: Narrator

text: from Jezer, the family of the Jezerites; from Shillem, the family of the Shillemites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were the families of Naphtali according to their families; and those numbered of them were 45,400.
speaker: Narrator

text: These were those numbered of the Israelites, 601,730.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “To these the land must be divided as an inheritance according to the number of the names.
speaker: Narrator

text: To a larger group you will give a larger inheritance, and to a smaller group you will give a smaller inheritance. To each one its inheritance must be given according to the number of people in it.
speaker: Narrator

text: The land must be divided by lot; and they will inherit in accordance with the names of their ancestral tribes.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their inheritance must be apportioned by lot among the larger and smaller groups.”
speaker: Narrator

text: And these are the Levites who were numbered according to their families: from Gershon, the family of the Gershonites; of Kohath, the family of the Kohathites; from Merari, the family of the Merarites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the families of the Levites: the family of the Libnites, the family of the Hebronites, the family of the Mahlites, the family of the Mushites, the family of the Korahites. Kohath became the father of Amram.
speaker: Narrator

text: Now the name of Amram’s wife was Jochebed, daughter of Levi, who was born to Levi in Egypt. And to Amram she bore Aaron, Moses, and Miriam their sister.
speaker: Narrator

text: And to Aaron were born Nadab and Abihu, Eleazar and Ithamar.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Nadab and Abihu died when they offered strange fire before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: Those of the Levites who were numbered were 23,000, all males from a month old and upward, for they were not numbered among the Israelites; no inheritance was given to them among the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: These are those who were numbered by Moses and Eleazar the priest, who numbered the Israelites in the rift valley plains of Moab along the Jordan River opposite Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: But there was not a man among these who had been among those numbered by Moses and Aaron the priest when they numbered the Israelites in the desert of Sinai.
speaker: Narrator

text: For the Lord had said of them, “They will surely die in the wilderness.” And there was not left a single man of them, except Caleb son of Jephunneh and Joshua son of Nun.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the daughters of Zelophehad son of Hepher, the son of Gilead, the son of Machir, the son of Manasseh of the families of Manasseh, the son of Joseph came forward. Now these are the names of his daughters: Mahlah, Noah, Hoglah, Milcah, and Tirzah.
speaker: Narrator

text: And they stood before Moses and Eleazar the priest and the leaders of the whole assembly at the entrance to the tent of meeting and said,
speaker: Narrator

text: “Our father died in the wilderness, although he was not part of the company of those that gathered themselves together against the Lord in the company of Korah, but he died for his own sin, and he had no sons.
speaker: Narrator

text: Why should the name of our father be lost from among his family because he had no son? Give us a possession among the relatives of our father.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses brought their case before the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord said to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “The daughters of Zelophehad have a valid claim. You must indeed give them possession of an inheritance among their father’s relatives, and you must transfer the inheritance of their father to them.
speaker: Narrator

text: And you must tell the Israelites, ‘If a man dies and has no son, then you must transfer his inheritance to his daughter;
speaker: Narrator

text: and if he has no daughter, then you are to give his inheritance to his brothers;
speaker: Narrator

text: and if he has no brothers, then you are to give his inheritance to his father’s brothers;
speaker: Narrator

text: and if his father has no brothers, then you are to give his inheritance to his relative nearest to him from his family, and he will possess it. This will be for the Israelites a legal requirement, as the Lord commanded Moses.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then the Lord said to Moses, “Go up this mountain of the Abarim range, and see the land I have given to the Israelites.
speaker: Narrator

text: When you have seen it, you will be gathered to your ancestors, as Aaron your brother was gathered to his ancestors.
speaker: Narrator

text: For in the wilderness of Zin when the community rebelled against me, you rebelled against my command to show me as holy before their eyes over the water—the water of Meribah in Kadesh in the wilderness of Zin.”
speaker: Narrator

text: Then Moses spoke to the Lord:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Let the Lord, the God of the spirits of all humankind, appoint a man over the community,
speaker: Narrator

text: who will go out before them, and who will come in before them, and who will lead them out, and who will bring them in, so that the community of the Lord may not be like sheep that have no shepherd.”
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord replied to Moses, “Take Joshua son of Nun, a man in whom is the Spirit, and lay your hand on him;
speaker: Narrator

text: set him before Eleazar the priest and before the whole community, and commission him publicly.
speaker: Narrator

text: Then you must delegate some of your authority to him, so that the whole community of the Israelites will be obedient.
speaker: Narrator

text: And he will stand before Eleazar the priest, who will seek counsel for him before the Lord by the decision of the Urim. At his command they will go out, and at his command they will come in, he and all the Israelites with him, the whole community.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses did as the Lord commanded him; he took Joshua and set him before Eleazar the priest and before the whole community.
speaker: Narrator

text: He laid his hands on him and commissioned him, just as the Lord commanded, by the authority of Moses.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Command the Israelites: ‘With regard to my offering, be sure to offer my food for my offering made by fire, as a pleasing aroma to me at its appointed time.’
speaker: Narrator

text: You will say to them, ‘This is the offering made by fire that you must offer to the Lord: two unblemished lambs one year old each day for a continual burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: The first lamb you must offer in the morning, and the second lamb you must offer in the late afternoon,
speaker: Narrator

text: with one-tenth of an ephah of finely ground flour as a grain offering mixed with one-quarter of a hin of pressed olive oil.
speaker: Narrator

text: It is a continual burnt offering that was instituted on Mount Sinai as a pleasing aroma, an offering made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘And its drink offering must be one-quarter of a hin for each lamb. You must pour out the strong drink as a drink offering to the Lord in the Holy Place.
speaker: Narrator

text: And the second lamb you must offer in the late afternoon; just as you offered the grain offering and drink offering in the morning, you must offer it as an offering made by fire, as a pleasing aroma to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the Sabbath day, you must offer two unblemished lambs a year old, and two-tenths of an ephah of finely ground flour as a grain offering, mixed with olive oil, along with its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: This is the burnt offering for every Sabbath, besides the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the first day of each month you must offer as a burnt offering to the Lord two young bulls, one ram, and seven unblemished lambs a year old,
speaker: Narrator

text: with three-tenths of an ephah of finely ground flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering for each bull, and two-tenths of an ephah of finely ground flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering for the ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one-tenth of an ephah of finely ground flour mixed with olive oil as a grain offering for each lamb, as a burnt offering for a pleasing aroma, an offering made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: For their drink offerings, include half a hin of wine with each bull, one-third of a hin for the ram, and one-fourth of a hin for each lamb. This is the burnt offering for each month throughout the months of the year.
speaker: Narrator

text: And one male goat must be offered to the Lord as a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fourteenth day of the first month is the Lord’s Passover.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the fifteenth day of this month is the festival. For seven days bread made without yeast must be eaten.
speaker: Narrator

text: And on the first day there is to be a holy assembly; you must do no ordinary work on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘But you must offer to the Lord an offering made by fire, a burnt offering of two young bulls, one ram, and seven lambs one year old; they must all be unblemished.
speaker: Narrator

text: And their grain offering is to be of finely ground flour mixed with olive oil. For each bull you must offer three-tenths of an ephah, and two-tenths for the ram.
speaker: Narrator

text: For each of the seven lambs you are to offer one-tenth of an ephah,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as one goat for a purification offering, to make atonement for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must offer these in addition to the burnt offering in the morning that is for a continual burnt offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: In this manner you must offer daily throughout the seven days the food of the sacrifice made by fire as a sweet aroma to the Lord. It is to be offered in addition to the continual burnt offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: On the seventh day you are to have a holy assembly, you must do no regular work.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Also, on the day of the firstfruits, when you bring a new grain offering to the Lord during your Feast of Weeks, you are to have a holy assembly. You must do no ordinary work.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must offer as the burnt offering, as a sweet aroma to the Lord, two young bulls, one ram, seven lambs one year old,
speaker: Narrator

text: with their grain offering of finely ground flour mixed with olive oil: three-tenths of an ephah for each bull, two-tenths for the one ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: with one-tenth for each of the seven lambs,
speaker: Narrator

text: as well as one male goat to make an atonement for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You are to offer them with their drink offerings in addition to the continual burnt offering and its grain offering—they must be unblemished.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the first day of the seventh month, you are to hold a holy assembly. You must not do your ordinary work, for it is a day of blowing trumpets for you.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must offer a burnt offering as a sweet aroma to the Lord: one young bull, one ram, and seven lambs one year old without blemish.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘Their grain offering is to be of finely ground flour mixed with olive oil, three-tenths of an ephah for the bull, two-tenths of an ephah for the ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one-tenth for each of the seven lambs,
speaker: Narrator

text: with one male goat for a purification offering to make an atonement for you;
speaker: Narrator

text: this is in addition to the monthly burnt offering and its grain offering, and the daily burnt offering with its grain offering and their drink offerings as prescribed, as a sweet aroma, a sacrifice made by fire to the Lord.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the tenth day of this seventh month you are to have a holy assembly. You must humble yourselves; you must not do any work on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must offer a burnt offering as a pleasing aroma to the Lord, one young bull, one ram, and seven lambs one year old, all of them without blemish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their grain offerings must be of finely ground flour mixed with olive oil, three-tenths of an ephah for the bull, two-tenths for the ram,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one-tenth for each of the seven lambs,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the purification offering for atonement and the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and their drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fifteenth day of the seventh month you are to have a holy assembly; you must do no ordinary work, and you must keep a festival to the Lord for seven days.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must offer a burnt offering, an offering made by fire as a pleasing aroma to the Lord: thirteen young bulls, two rams, and fourteen lambs each one year old, all of them without blemish.
speaker: Narrator

text: Their grain offerings must be of finely ground flour mixed with olive oil, three-tenths of an ephah for each of the thirteen bulls, two-tenths of an ephah for each of the two rams,
speaker: Narrator

text: and one-tenth for each of the fourteen lambs,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the second day you must offer twelve young bulls, two rams, fourteen lambs one year old, all without blemish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and their grain offerings and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, according to their number as prescribed,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and their drink offerings.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the third day you must offer eleven bulls, two rams, fourteen lambs one year old, all without blemish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and their grain offerings and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, according to their number as prescribed,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fourth day you must offer ten bulls, two rams, and fourteen lambs one year old, all without blemish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and their grain offerings and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, according to their number as prescribed,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the fifth day you must offer nine bulls, two rams, and fourteen lambs one year old, all without blemish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and their grain offerings and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, according to their number as prescribed,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the sixth day you must offer eight bulls, two rams, and fourteen lambs one year old, all without blemish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and their grain offering and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, according to their number as prescribed,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the seventh day you must offer seven bulls, two rams, and fourteen lambs one year old, all without blemish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and their grain offerings and their drink offerings for the bulls, for the rams, and for the lambs, according to their number as prescribed,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘On the eighth day you are to have a holy assembly; you must do no ordinary work on it.
speaker: Narrator

text: But you must offer a burnt offering, an offering made by fire, as a pleasing aroma to the Lord, one bull, one ram, seven lambs one year old, all of them without blemish,
speaker: Narrator

text: and with their grain offerings and their drink offerings for the bull, for the ram, and for the lambs, according to their number as prescribed,
speaker: Narrator

text: along with one male goat for a purification offering, in addition to the continual burnt offering with its grain offering and its drink offering.
speaker: Narrator

text: “‘These things you must present to the Lord at your appointed times, in addition to your vows and your freewill offerings, as your burnt offerings, your grain offerings, your drink offerings, and your peace offerings.’”
speaker: Narrator

text: (30:1) So Moses told the Israelites everything, just as the Lord had commanded him.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses told the leaders of the tribes concerning the Israelites, “This is what the Lord has commanded:
speaker: Narrator

text: If a man makes a vow to the Lord or takes an oath of binding obligation on himself, he must not break his word, but must do whatever he has promised.
speaker: Narrator

text: “If a young woman who is still living in her father’s house makes a vow to the Lord or places herself under an obligation,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her father hears of her vow or the obligation to which she has pledged herself, and her father remains silent about her, then all her vows will stand, and every obligation to which she has pledged herself will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her father overrules her when he hears about it, then none of her vows or her obligations that she has pledged for herself will stand. And the Lord will release her from it, because her father overruled her.
speaker: Narrator

text: “And if she marries a husband while under a vow, or she uttered anything impulsively by which she has pledged herself,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her husband hears about it but remains silent about her when he hears about it, then her vows will stand and her obligations that she has pledged for herself will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if when her husband hears it he overrules her, then he will nullify the vow she has taken, and whatever she uttered impulsively that she has pledged for herself. And the Lord will release her from it.
speaker: Narrator

text: “But every vow of a widow or of a divorced woman which she has pledged for herself will remain intact.
speaker: Narrator

text: If she made the vow in her husband’s house or put herself under obligation with an oath,
speaker: Narrator

text: and her husband heard about it, but remained silent about her, and did not overrule her, then all her vows will stand, and every obligation which she pledged for herself will stand.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband clearly nullifies them when he hears them, then whatever she says by way of vows or obligations will not stand. Her husband has made them void, and the Lord will release her from them.
speaker: Narrator

text: “Any vow or sworn obligation that would bring affliction to her, her husband can confirm or nullify.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if her husband remains completely silent about her from day to day, he thus confirms all her vows or all her obligations which she is under; he confirms them because he remained silent about her when he heard them.
speaker: Narrator

text: But if he should nullify them after he has heard them, then he will bear her iniquity.”
speaker: Narrator

text: These are the statutes that the Lord commanded Moses, relating to a man and his wife, and a father and his young daughter who is still living in her father’s house.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Lord spoke to Moses:
speaker: Narrator

text: “Exact vengeance for the Israelites from the Midianites—after that you will be gathered to your people.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses spoke to the people: “Arm men from among you for the war, to attack the Midianites and to execute the Lord’s vengeance on Midian.
speaker: Narrator

text: You must send to the battle 1,000 men from every tribe throughout all the tribes of Israel.”
speaker: Narrator

text: So 1,000 from every tribe, 12,000 armed for battle in all, were provided out of the thousands of Israel.
speaker: Narrator

text: So Moses sent them to the war, 1,000 from every tribe, with Phinehas son of Eleazar the priest, who was in charge of the holy articles and the signal trumpets.
speaker: Narrator

text: They fought against the Midianites, as the Lord commanded Moses, and they killed every male.
speaker: Narrator

text: They killed the kings of Midian in addition to those slain—Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba—five Midianite kings. They also killed Balaam son of Beor with the sword.
speaker: Narrator

text: The Israelites took the women of Midian captive along with their little ones, and took all their herds, all their flocks, and all their goods as plunder.
speaker: Narrator

text: They burned all their towns where they lived and all their encampments.
speaker: Narrator

text: They took all the plunder and all the spoils, both people and animals.
speaker: Narrator

text: They brought the captives and the spoils and the plunder to Moses, to Eleazar the priest, and to the Israelite community, to the camp on the rift valley plains of Moab, along the Jordan River across from Jericho.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses, Eleazar the priest, and all the leaders of the community went out to meet them outside the camp.
speaker: Narrator

text: But Moses was furious with the officers of the army, the commanders over thousands and commanders over hundreds, who had come from service in the war.
speaker: Narrator

text: Moses said to them, “Have you allowed all the women to live?
speaker: Narrator

text: Look, these people through the counsel of Balaam caused the Israelites to act treacherously against the Lord in the matter of Peor—which resulted in the plague among the community of the Lord!
speaker: Narrator

text: Now therefore kill every boy, and kill every woman who has been intimate with a man in bed.
